metadata.title: Ternary Tin Selenium Sulfide (SnSe0.5S0.5) Nano Alloy as the High-Performance Anodes for Lithium-Ion and Sodium-Ion Batteries

sections.text:
Metal sulfides have received tremendous attention due to their superior electrochemical
performance. In this study, it is the first time that the ternary tin selenium sulfide, SnSe0.5S0.5, was investigated as a potential high-performance anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). The SnSe0.5S0.5/C nanocomposites have also been synthesized through a facile polyol-method followed by a simple hydrothermal process and subsequent sintering. The material demonstrated a high specific capacity and a long-term cycling stability in both Li-ion and Na-ion batteries (625 mA h g -1 for LIB at 500 mA g -1 rate after 1000 cycles, 430 mA h g -1 in a SIB at 200 mA g -1 rate after 100 cycles). Furthermore, the kinetic analysis of Liions and Na-ions storage revealed that the extrinsic pseudocapacitive contribution could improve the charge transfer rate during the insertion and extraction of Li-ion and Na-ion, thus enhancing
*Corresponding author E-mail address: junwei.wu@hit.edu.cn (J. Wu) E-mail address: qud@uwm.edu (D. Qu)
the rate performance and cycling stability. These results demonstrated that the novel tin selenium sulfide (SnSe0.5S0.5) material could potentially be an excellent anode material for Li-ion storage and Na-ion storage.
Graphical Abstract
A new anode material for Li-ion and Na-ion batteries is synthesized via a facile polyolmethod and hydrothermal process. It consists of SnSe0.5S0.5 nano alloy encapsulated in carbon bulk and surrounded by carbon spheres. A high specific capacity and excellent cycling stability are achieved (625 mA h g  for LIB at 500 mA g  rate after 1000 discharge/charge cycles, and 430 mA h g  in a SIB at 200 mA g  rate after 100 cycles).
Keywords: Anode; Lithium-ion batteries; Sodium-ion batteries; SnSe0.5S0.5; Long cycling
stability.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Energy storage and conversion play an increasingly important role in our daily life.
Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have become state-of-art, while sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have gained wide attention in the last few years. LIBs are mainly used in portable electronic devices and electrical vehicles because of their high energy density and power density, and SIBs are mainly used for energy storage e.g. in the smart grid applications due to the low cost and environmentally friendliness [1-4]. Various electrode materials have been studied recently aiming for the performance improvement. Among the anode materials, graphite was extensively used as LIBs anode with a high energy density (372 mA h g -1 ) and excellent cycling performance. However, graphite can’t be used in SIBs owning to the small inter-layer space, which impedes effective Na-ions insertion [5]. Hard carbon with larger interlayer space behaved better as SIBs anode, but the high cost and low capacity (less than 300 mA h g -1 ) made it less attractive [6]. Therefore, the development of the novel anode materials with high energy density, low cost, and long cycle life as a substitute of carbon materials in LIBs and SIBs has aroused intensive research interests. It has been suggested that Sn, Sb, Pb, and P which can alloy with Na to deliver higher capacity, seem to be good alternatives [7-10].
Tin has been considered as one of the most promising anode materials for both LIBs and
SIBs owning to its low cost (roughly 20 $ USkg -1 ), high capacity (993.4 mA h g -1 ; from Sn to Li4.4Sn and 847 mA h g -1 ; from Sn to Na3.75Sn) and environmentally benign [11,12]. However, the huge volume change during delithiation (260%) and desodiation (400%) results in the
pulverization issue and aggregation of tin-based materials which leads to the poor cycle life [12,13]. To mitigate the issue, a tremendous amount of efforts have been conducted over the last
few decades which can generally be categorized into two types: firstly, minimizing the particle size into nanoscale which could degrade the mechanical strain during the processing of alloying and dealloying reaction with Li-ions and Na-ions, thus protecting the structure integrity [14-16]; secondly, combining tin with other conductive frame (such as carbon materials) at nanometer can not only buffer the volume expansion during the cycling, but also prevent nanoparticle aggregation and enhance the electronic conductivity [17-19]. In addition, nanostructure also guarantees a short transport path for Li-ions and Na-ion to enhance the electrochemical performance. Therefore, a large number of tin or tin compound (SnO/SnO2, SnS2/SnS, Sn4P3 et.al) nano-structured particles and carbon composites such as Sn-rGO [20],SnO2-CNT [21],SnS-rGO [7] etc. had been studied and exhibited improved electrochemical properties for
Li and Na ions storage.
Se, a chalcogen group element sharing similar chemical properties with sulfur, has a high
electronic conductivity (1 × 10 -3 S m -1 ) comparing with that of S (5 × 10 -28 S m -1 ) [22] and outstanding volumetric capacity as the electrode materials for Li-Se and Na-Se batteries
[23,24].Many efforts have been devoted to exploring the electrochemical performance of
selenium in LIBs and SIBs. It has been demonstrated that Se-doping could improve cycling
stability and efficiency of tin-based materials for LIBs and SIBs[25,26]. However, all the
aforementioned materials are classified as binary tin-based compounds contained only mono SnA covalent bonds (A represents any element other than Sn). The ternary tin chalcogenide has rarely been reported as a battery active material.
In this work, we successfully synthesized a nanostructured ternary tin selenium sulfide
(SnSe0.5S0.5) through a facile polyol-method. The SnSe0.5S0.5C nanocomposites were then obtained followed by a normal hydrothermal method and subsequent sintering. When utilized as
anodes for LIB and SIB, the SnSe0.5S0.5C composites present an outstanding cycling stability (625 mA h g -1 for LIB at current density of 500 mA g -1 after 1000 cycles, 430 mA h g -1 in a SIB at 200 mA g -1 rate after 100 cycles) and remarkable rate capability (389 mA h g -1 at 5 A g -1 for LIB, 506 mA h g -1 at 1 A g -1 for SIB) with almost 100% coulombic efficiency. In addition, we
demonstrate that the extrinsic pseudocapacitive behavior could improve the charge transfer rate during the insertion and extraction of Li-ion and Na-ion, which contributes to the excellent rate performance and cycling stability.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
All materials were purchased from commercial sources and used as-received without any
further purifications. Sulphur powders (S, 99.5%, AR), selenium powders (Se, 99.9%, 200 mesh),
diethylene glycol (DEG, 99.0%), absolute alcohol (AR) and D-Glucose (C6H12O6·H2O, AR) were purchased from Aladdin; ethylenediamine (EN, 99.0%, AR) was from Guangzhou Panyu
Liqiang Chemical Technology Co., Ltd; tin (+4) chloride pentahydrate (SnCl4·5H2O,99.0%) was purchased from Yonghua Chemical Technology (Jiangsu) Co., Ltd.; deionized water was prepared by McNair Technology Co., Ltd.
2.2. Synthesis of SnSe0.5S0.5 Nano Alloy
SnSe0.5S0.5 was synthesized by a rapid polyol-method. In a typical synthesis process, 0.32 g
sulphur powders and 0.79 g selenium powders were mixed by grinding in an agate mortar. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred into a 250 mL N2 statured three-necked round-bottom flask with 45 ml DEG under stirring for 10 minutes, 2 mL EN was then added with vigorous stirring and further refluxed at 140 °C on an oil bath. After 30 minutes, 3.5 g SnCl4·5H2O (0.01 mol) was added and the solution was kept on refluxing at 180-200 °C for 2 h under stirring.
During this procedure, the color of the solution turned from wine red to brown gradually. The mixture was then washed with absolute alcohol and deionized water by a high-speed centrifugation (8600 rmin -1 ) several times to remove residual solution. It was subsequently dried
overnight at 80 °C into brown powders. Finally, the SnSe0.5S0.5 was obtained after further heating the brown powders at 500 °C for 4 h under argon atmosphere to remove residual elemental sulphur.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of SnSe0.5S0.5/C Nanocomposites
sections.text:
SnSe0.5S0.5C composites were synthesized via a hydrothermal method followed by
calcination. In a typical experiment, at first, 0.3 g as-synthesized brown powders in section 2.2 were dispersed into 20 mL 0.5 mol L -1 aqueous glucose solution by ultrasonic processing for 30 minutes. The resulting suspension was then transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (30 mL in capacity) and heated at 180 °C for 3 h in an air-flow electric oven. The dark grey product was collected by vacuum filtration and washed with absolute alcohol and deionized water, and then dried overnight at 80 °C in oven. Finally, the SnSe0.5S0.5/C composites (dark powders) were gained after annealing above product at 500 °C for 4 h under argon temperature.

sections.heading: 2.4. Materials Characterization
sections.text:
The crystalline structure and phase composition of the as-prepared samples were
characterized using a powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku DMax-2500 with Cu Kα radiation) between 10° and 85° (2) at a scan rate of 5° min -1 . The morphology of product was
analyzed by Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM, HITACHI, SU8010) operating at 15 KV and EDS were also carried out. The details of the structure were investigated by a High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2011). Selected-
Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) patterns were collected with a Gatan charge-coupled device (CCD) camera. The chemical composition and the bonding structure were determined by XPS spectra (AXIS-Ultra from Kratos Analytical with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (225 W, 15 mA, 15 kV)). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the samples was carried outed in a dry air condition with the temperature scan from 30 °C to 800 °C at the rate of 5 °C min -1 by SHIMADZU DTG-60.

sections.heading: 2.5 Electrochemical Measurements
sections.text:
The electrochemical properties were measured using coin cells (CR2032) with lithium or
sodium metal as counter electrode. The working electrode was prepared by mixing the active
materials (as-synthesized SnSe0.5S0.5 or SnSe0.5S0.5C powders), carbon black (super P) and binders (CMC) in a weight ratio of 7:1.5:1.5 casted on a Cu foil (The loading amount of the active materials on the copper foil was ≈1.0 mg cm -2 and the electrode diameter was 10 mm). The cathode and anode were separated by a Celgard 2300 microporous membrane. The CR2032-
type coin cells were assembled in argon temperature glove box (Mikrouna Universal 2440750),
where both H2O and O2 levels were kept below 0.1 ppm. For lithium ion batteries, the electrolyte consisted of 1 mol L -1
LiPF6 in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC)dimethyl carbonate (DEC)
(1:1 vol%, Shenzhen CAPCHEM Technology Co. Ltd.) with addition of 5% Fluoroethylene Carbonate (FEC). For sodium ion batteries, the electrolyte was 1 mol L -1
NaClO4 in a mixture of
EC/DEC (1:1 vol%) with 5% FEC as additive. The detail roles played by the additive are still under investigation, but it was believed that the electrolyte additive of FEC enabled SnSe0.5S0.5/C anode to form a compact and stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layers, thus to improve the
cycling performance [8,27]. The galvanostatic chargedischarge tests were performed with a
NeWare BTS (accuracy: 0.1%) at room temperature. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed
with a CHI1000C electrochemistry workstation (CH instrument, Shanghai). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out using a Gamry Instrument with the frequency range from 100 000 Hz to 0.01Hz after one cycle.

sections.heading: 3 Results and discussion
sections.text:
Polyol-method is one of the most popular and facile approaches that focus on the
preparation of nanostructured metals and alloys, in which the high-boiling alcohol (such as glycerol or glycol) often acts a powerful agent that effectively limits particles size and prevents
aggregation [28]. The major synthetic routes of the SnSe0.5S0.5C nanocomposites are illustrated in Fig. 1. Firstly, sulphur and selenium powders were dissolved into the diethylene glycol (DEG, C4H10O3) and the ethylenediamine (EN, C2H8N2) was then added in three-neck flask where the mixture was refluxed at appropriate temperature on an oil bath. DEG is used as a solvent and EN
is a chelating agent and reductant [29,30].Subsequently, tin sources (SnCl4·5H2O) were dissolved into the mixture. During this progress, Sn 4 was reduced by EN to form Sn 2 and thus
obtain SnSe0.5S0.5 under the polyol environment, which could be monitored by observing the change of reaction solution color (Fig. S1) turning from wine red to brown. Finally, in order to avoid aggregation and get dispersed SnSe0.5S0.5 nanoparticles, the SnSe0.5S0.5 were combined with carbon by reacting with glucose in Teflon autoclave followed by calcination in Ar atmosphere.
Fig. 2a shows the XRD pattern of the as-prepared SnSe0.5S0.5C composite material. The
comparison of SnSe0.5S0.5 before and after sintering can be observed in Fig. S2a and b, Supporting Information. All the diffraction peaks matched to the indexed to SnSe0.5S0.5 very well (space group: Pnma, PDF # 48-1225), suggesting its high purity. The main diffraction peaks (Fig. S2c) located at 25.7°, 27.1°, 30.1°, 31.1°, 31.6° and 38.5° can be assigned to the (201), (210),
(011), (111), (400), and (311) planes, respectively. The carbon coating didn’t seem to alter the crystal structure. Fig. 2b shows the zig-zag structure along the b axis of SnSe0.5S0.5, the orthorhombic structure belongs to Pbmn (62) space group (a 11.35 Å, b 4.06 Å, c 4.38 Å).
In the novel structure of the material, the atoms of Se and S occupy the same sites showed in yellow in the schematic diagram of crystal structure (Fig. 2b). The atoms in each layer were joined with three nearest adjacent atoms by covalent bond, creating a strong layered structure
similar as SnS and SnSe [31,32], which could ensure the rapid insertiondesertion processes of
both Li ions and Na ions and limit the volume change.
To analyze the surface composition of SnSe0.5S0.5C composite and study the chemical states
of Sn, Se, S and C elements, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and electron diffraction spectroscopy (EDS) were applied. The XPS survey scan spectrum (Fig. 2c) shows the main
elements were Sn, Se, S, C and O in SnSe0.5S0.5C composite. In the high-resolution Sn 3d spectrum (Fig. 2d), the samples with and without carbon were compared. The Sn 3d spectrum of SnSe0.5S0.5 shows two obvious peaks located in 486.8 eV (3d5/2) and 495.2 eV (3d3/2), which could be assigned to the reformation of Sn-S and Sn-Se bonds, respectively. It was evident that ethylenediamine (EN) successfully reduced Sn 4 to Sn 2 through an indirect reduction
mechanism [33]. Interestingly, the Sn was at its +4 oxidation state in the carbon composite where the Sn 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks shift to a corresponding higher binding energy (487.3 eV and 495.7 eV respectively) from the non-coated SnSe0.5S0.5. Evidentially, Sn 2+ participated in reducing glucose to carbon. Since XPS can only detect the top surface of a sample, Sn 2+ nearing the surface of the sample was likely to react with the glucose resulting the partial oxidization of Sn 2+ to Sn 4+ during the hydrothermal process [34]. The high resolution Se 3d, S 2p, C 1s spectra in Fig. S3, Supporting Information, reveal the binding energy and valence state of Se, S and C
elements. The Se 3d line of SnSe0.5S0.5C (Fig. S3a) can be separated into two parts: intermediate fit and selenide fit. For selenide fit, two obvious peaks at 54.2 eV and 55.0 eV correspond to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Se  ; for intermediate fit, two peaks at 55.8 eV and 56.6 eV roughly correlate to Se  . Thus, it can be explained that there is excessive selenium in the product [35,36]. Two peaks at 161.8 eV and 164.2 eV of S 2p in Fig. S3b, can be ascribed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of S  , respectively. The carbon spectrum (Fig. S3c) can be separated into four peaks at 284.7 eV, 285.4
eV, 286.5 eV and 289.0 eV, which were corresponded to the binding of CCCC, CN, CO
and OCO. The appearance of CN bond was due to the fact that the polyol-reaction process
was surrounded by N2. The EDS results of the composites are shown in Fig. S4, in which the atomic ratios of C, S, Se and Sn elements was approximately 65.4: 8.7: 7.0: 18.9 or the molar ratio of Sn, Se, S was 2:1:1, confirming the SnSe0.5S0.5 stoichiometry. In addition, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted to determine the content of the carbon in the SnSe0.5S0.5/C. As shown in Fig. S5 in supplementary material, the weight loss between 340~520 °C can be assigned to the carbon burn out following the pyrolyzation of SnSe0.5S0.5 starting around 560 °C. The content of carbon in the SnSe0.5S0.5/C is 35.2%.
The morphology and microstructure of the product were characterized by scanning electron
microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Fig. 3a and b show the SEM
morphology of SnSe0.5S0.5C. It can be seen that substantial amount of carbon spheres were homogenously dispersed on the sample surface with a diameter around 300 nm. The morphology of SnSe0.5S0.5 was shown in Fig. S6, Supporting Information, as a reference. TEM analyses provided worthwhile structural information of SnSe0.5S0.5C. Two different carbon formations in the SnSe0.5S0.5C composites, carbon sphere and carbon bulk, can be observed from the TEM images in Fig. 3c, d and f, g. More details of the structure are exhibited in Fig. S7. Strikingly, the
SnSe0.5S0.5 nanoparticles with a size ranging from several nanometers to several micrometers were either surrounded by carbon sphere or homogeneously encapsulated in carbon bulk. The carbon structure could act as a conductor matrix to rise up the conductivity and a cushion to accommodate the severe volume change during cycling [37,38]. The HRTEM images (Fig. 3e
and h) demonstrate the formation of SnSe0.5S0.5C nanostructures. Meanwhile, clear lattice fringes with a space of 0.288 nm and 0.305 nm corresponding to the (111) and (011) plane of SnSe0.5S0.5 can be identified, which match with the XRD results (Fig. 2a). Furthermore, the large layered spacing was favorable to intercalation of Li  and Na  . The selected area electron
diffraction (SAED) patterns (insets of Fig. 3e and h) prove that the SnSe0.5S0.5 nanoparticles are polycrystalline. Elemental mapping analyses depicted in Fig. 3i illustrate the homogeneous distribution of Sn, Se, S and C elements, which verify the formation of a perfect carbon composite.
Fig. 4a shows the cyclic voltammetry (CV) of the first five cycles of the SnSe0.5S0.5C
composite electrode in 1 mol L -1
LiPF6 ethylene carbonate (EC)dimethyl carbonate (DEC)
electrolyte at the scan-rate of 0.1 mVs -1 with the voltage range from 0.01 V to 3 V (vs. Li  Li).
The distinctive reduction peak at 1.16 V during the first cathodic scan could be attributed to the irreversible decomposition of SnSe0.5S0.5 [39]. The large and broad reduction peak between 0.6 and 0 V could be assigned to the decomposition of electrolyte, thus the formation of the SEI layer and the electrochemical alloying reaction between Sn and Li [40]. It is worth pointing out that the board and multiple peaks reduction profile make it evident that the Li may reside in
various locations of different energies in the SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode. During the anodic scan, the peaks at the voltage range of 0-0.8 V can be assigned to the delithiation of Li-Sn alloy and the board background at around 1.25 V was related to the extraction from carbon [41]. The CV
curves after the first cycle show high reversibility, implying high cycling performance of
SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode.
The electrochemical performance of the SnSe0.5S0.5C composites as an anode in a LIB was
tested by the galvanostatic discharge/charge technique. Fig. 4b displays the cycle performance of the SnSe0.5S0.5C anode at the current density of 0.2 A g -1 . After 150 cycles, the electrode delivered a high discharge specific capacity of 785 mA h g -1 , corresponding to a capacity retention of 92.5% (in comparison of the discharge capacity of the second cycle). Fig. 4c and d
show the rate performance of SnSe0.5S0.5C anode at different current density between 0.01 V to 3 V. The composite electrode delivered the discharge specific capacity of 989, 830, 729, 673, 646, 553, 389 mA h g -1 at the current density of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.8, 1.0, 2.0, 5.0 A g -1 , respectively. After cycling at higher current density, the capacity returned to and remained at 832 mA h g -1 when the current density returned to initial 0.1 A g -1 . These results demonstrated the excellent
rate performance of SnSe0.5S0.5C composites.
As shown in Fig. 4e, after 1000 cycles at a current density of 0.5 A g -1 , the capacity of the
composite electrode still remained at 625 mA h g -1 with almost 100% coulombic efficiency. The capacity increase after about 100 cycles shown in Fig. 4e may be due to the improvement of the lithium ions accessibility in composite materials with carbon during the cycling process [42,43].
The SnSe0.5S0.5C composite materials also demonstrated impressive performance as the
anode in a SIB. Fig. 5a shows the CV of the first five cycles for the SnSe0.5S0.5C anode in a 1 mol L -1 NaClO4 ECDEC electrolyte at the scan-rate of 0.1 mVs -1 and voltages ranging from 0.01 to 3 V vs. Na  Na. During the first reduction scan, the irreversible peak at 0.6 V, which
disappeared in the subsequent cycles, can be ascribed to the irreversible SEI formation and the
decomposition of SnSe0.5S0.5C [44]. The two reversible peaks in the subsequent reductions could
be assigned to the Na alloying reaction with the anode material. In the reverse anodic scan, the various oxidation peaks from 0.3 to 1.75 V could be attributed to the desodiation processes. Obviously, the multiple redox peaks in the CV revealed the complexity for the conversion reaction, which mechanism was still not clear. But the reversibility of sodiation and desodiation was clearly demonstrated by the cyclic voltammetry scans.
Fig. 5b shows the galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles for the first two cycles at a current
density of 0.2 A g -1
. The first discharge and recharge capacities of SnSe0.5S0.5/C anode for SIBs
were approximately 625 mA h g - and 437 mA h g -1 , respectively, and the first coulombic
efficiency (CE) was about 70%. After a few cycles, the CE value was close to 100%. The rate performance of SnSe0.5S0.5C anode for SIBs at various current densities from 0.1 A g -1 to 1 A g -1 is revealed in Fig. 5c and d. When the current gradually increase (0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.8, 1 A g -1 ), the delivered discharge capacities were 683, 612, 549, 525, 506 mA h g -1 , correspondingly. Fig. 5e
shows the cycle life of SnSe0.5S0.5C composites electrode in SIBs. After 100 cycles, this electrode still maintains discharge capacity of 430 mA h g -1 and close to 100% CE. Compared
with SnSe0.5S0.5 electrode (Fig. S8), SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode shows more advanced specific capacity and stable cycling performance owning to the easier charge transfer and the great buffer effect of the carbon. The comparison of the electrochemical performances of SnSe0.5S0.5/C anode with that of the previously reported alloys are tabulated in Table S1 and S2 [3,7,8,11,12,21,27,37,38,45-58]. The SnSe0.5S0.5/C anode clearly demonstrated superior performances in terms of the rate capability, the reversibility and the stability.
The merits of the SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode were further confirmed by electrochemical
impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis. Fig. 6 shows the Nyquist plots of the SnSe0.5S0.5 and SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode for LIBs and SIBs in the first cycle. The equivalent circuit model is
provided in Fig. 6c. According to previous reports [59], Rs represents contact resistance between the electrode and electrolyte, Rct and CPE1 are associated with the charge transfer resistance and constant phase element, and Zw is the Warburg impedance related to Li + and Na + diffusion through bulk electrodes. As shown in Fig. 6a and b, the high frequency semicircle is a good indicator of the charge-transfer resistance (Rct), and the low frequency ranges are assigned to the Wraburg diffusion process (Zw). It can be seen that the charge transfer resistance of SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode is 66.2 Ω and 166.9 Ω for LIB and SIB, respectively, which is less than that of SnSe0.5S0.5 electrodes. The detail fitting results for LIBs and SIBs were listed in Table S3, Supporting Information. In addition, combining with the previous morphology and structure characterization results, the carbon spheres and bulk could contribute to the advanced
performances of SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode.
In order to quantitatively study the charge storage mechanism of the SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode
for lithiumsodium ion batteries, a series of CV curves were carried out at various sweep rates.
For lithium ion batteries, Fig. 7a shows the typical cyclic voltammograms for SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode at the sweep rates from 0.1 to 1.2 mVs -1 . The area of closed CV curves represents the
total charge storage from both faradaic and non-faradaic process. The redox peaks represent the lithium ions insertion and extraction process in electrode, respectively.
To date, the total charge storage can be separated into two components: firstly, the diffusion
contribution from intercalationconversionalloying process from the charge transfer with
surface/subsurface atoms; secondly, the capacitive contribution from the electrical double-layer effect [60]. According to previous reports [60,61], the relationship between measured current (i) and scan rate (v) as following: 𝑖 = a𝑣𝑏. (1)
𝑖 = b 𝑣 + 𝑎 (2)
Where a and b are both variable parameters. The b value determined by the slope of 𝑖 versus
𝑣 in equation (2) could be assigned to two conditions: b=0.5 and b=1.0. As b=0.5, the current response is diffusion-controlled; as b=1, the current is controlled by capacitive processes. b-value of SnSe0.5S0.5/C electrode is shown in Fig. 7b, and more detail can be obtained from Fig. S9, Supporting Information. On the basis of Fig. 7a and Eq. (1) and (2), the calculated average bvalue is 0.78, which suggests that the capacitance contribution can’t be ignored. This same phenomenon had been observed in other chalcogenide electrodes, such as SnS, SnS2, MoS2, FeS2 [61-64]. To further quantitatively analyze the ratios of Li-ions capacitance contribution, the current respond can be separated to surface capacitive effect (𝑘1𝑣) and diffusion controlled process (𝑘2𝑣 0.5) at a fixed voltage [61]: 𝑖(𝑉) = 𝑘1𝑣 + 𝑘2𝑣 0.5 (3) 𝑖(𝑉) 𝑣0.5⁄ = 𝑘1 + 𝑘2𝑣 0.5 (4)
Where 𝑘1 and 𝑘2 are both constants and 𝑣 is the scan rate. According to Eq. (3) and (4), it is
possible to confirm the fraction of current from two different charge storage processes by determining the value of 𝑘1 and 𝑘2 at a special voltage. As a result, 78.9% of capacitive contribution arises from pseudocapacitive processes at 0.8 mV s -1 , which is shown by the grey region in Fig. 7c. With the increase of scan rate, furthermore, the ratio of diffusion contribution gradually shrinks, but the effect of the capacitance further enlarges (Fig. 7d) with a maximum contribution value of 82.3% at the sweep rate of 1.2 mVs -1 . The results reveal that there is
pseudocapacitive processes during charge storage in SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode, which is favorable for high rate and long-term cycling performance [61, 64]. Similar analysis was applied to Na-ion batteries as well, a higher capacitive contribution in SIBs was displayed because of the larger
radius of sodium-ions (Fig. S10) [65].
According to the above analysis, the outstanding electrochemical properties of SnSe0.5S0.5C
composites electrode for LIB and SIB could be ascribed to the following reasons: (1) the
nanosized SnSe0.5S0.5particles may degrade the mechanical strain during the processing of alloying and dealloying reaction with Li-ions and Na-ions, thus protecting the structure integrity of electrode and shorting the ions diffusion pathway in SnSe0.5S0.5. (2) The large inter-layer space is favorable to the intercalation of Li ions and large Na ions, when accommodated in the large inter-layers, the volume change during the cycling can be relieved to ensure the integrity of the intrinsic structure. (3) The higher intrinsic conductivity of Se than that of S can increase the conductivity of chalcogenide materials, which contributes to the high rate performance. (4) The carbon morphologies (sphere and bulk) can form a highly conductive matrix, and may also function as a cushion to buffer the volume change and alleviate aggregation of SnSe0.5S0.5 during electrochemical processing. (5) Partial extrinsic pseudocapacitive processes are favorable to fast
kinetics of an alloying-based SnSe0.5S0.5C electrode.
In addition, the 3 V cut-off voltage seemed high for both LIB and SIB anodes, but it is
worth to point out that close to 80% of the capacity was below 2.0 V, which should have minimum impact in a full cell. High conversion potential remains an intrinsic problem for the alloy based materials. In order to mitigate the issue, it is necessary that the thermodynamics and kinetics of the processes are better understood through the continuous fundamental investigation.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, SnSe0.5S0.5C nanocomposites have been successfully synthesized by a rapid
polyol-method and followed by a hydrothermal treatment. Benefiting from the stable nanostructure and good conductivity, the nanocomposites can effectively restrict the large volume changes and help the active materials to fully complete the electrochemical reaction, thus demonstrated its potential to be excellent anodes for both LIBs and SIBs. This composite electrode exhibited high reversible discharge capacity e.g. 989 mA h g -1 at 0.1 A g -1 and 625 mA h g -1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 A g -1 and excellent rate performance 389 mA h g -1 at 5 A g -1 as an LIB anode. While reversible capacity of 430 mA h g -1 at 0.2 A g -1 after 100 cycles was demonstrated as an anode in a SIB with excellent rate capacity e.g. 683 mA h g -1 at 0.1 A g -1 and 506 mA h g -1 at 1 A g -1 . EIS and CV analyses reveal that the impressive electrochemical
performance of the SnSe0.5S0.5C is ascribed to the enhanced reaction kinetics. These results demonstrate SnSe0.5S0.5C nanocomposites material could be applied to LIBs and SIBs and exhibit a high capacity, excellent cycling and rate performances.

Q. M. would also like to thank Dr. Xiaoqing Yang, Dr. Xianyong Wu and Dr. Hui Zhang at McNair Technology Co., LTD laboratories for several useful discussions.

metadata.abstractText: Metal sulfides have received tremendous attention due to their superior electrochemical performance. In this study, it is the first time that the ternary tin selenium sulfide, SnSe0.5S0.5, was investigated as a potential high-performance anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). The SnSe0.5S0.5/C nanocomposites have also been synthesized through a facile polyol-method followed by a simple hydrothermal process and subsequent sintering. The material demonstrated a high specific capacity and a long-term cycling stability in both Li-ion and Na-ion batteries (625 mA h g -1 for LIB at 500 mA g -1 rate after 1000 cycles, 430 mA h g -1 in a SIB at 200 mA g -1 rate after 100 cycles). Furthermore, the kinetic analysis of Liions and Na-ions storage revealed that the extrinsic pseudocapacitive contribution could improve the charge transfer rate during the insertion and extraction of Li-ion and Na-ion, thus enhancing Corresponding author E-mail address: junwei.wu@hit.edu.cn (J. Wu) E-mail address: qud@uwm.edu (D. Qu)
metadata.creator: Elsevier
